metadata.title: Revisiting Decomposable Submodular Function Minimization with Incidence Relations
metadata.author: Pan Li, Olgica Milenkovic
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We introduce a new approach to decomposable submodular function minimization (DSFM) that exploits incidence relations. Incidence relations describe which variables effectively influence the component functions, and when properly utilized, they allow for improving the convergence rates of DSFM solvers. Our main results include the precise parametrization of the DSFM problem based on incidence relations, the development of new scalable alternative projections and parallel coordinate descent methods and an accompanying rigorous analysis of their convergence rates.

highlights: A set function F : 2[N] → R over a ground set [N ] is termed submodular if for all pairs of sets S1, S2 ⊆ [N ], one has F (S1) + F (S2) ≥ F (S1 ∩ S2) + F (S1 ∪ S2)
Among the various submodular function optimization problems, submodular function minimization (SFM), which may be stated as minS⊆[N] F (S), is one of the most important and commonly studied questions
We provide a complete theoretical analysis of the algorithms parametrized by incidence relations with respect to their convergence rates
We propose two CDMs which rely on parallel projections and incidence relations
I.e., by setting μ 1 = N R, one always has θP 1,∞ ≥ αN R, which shows that parallelization cannot improve the convergence rate of the random CD method

random CD method-G offers a much better convergence rate than random CD method-U since the sampling probability P produced by the greedy algorithm leads to a smaller value of θP 1,∞ compared to

summary: A set function F : 2[N] → R over a ground set [N ] is termed submodular if for all pairs of sets S1, S2 ⊆ [N ], one has F (S1) + F (S2) ≥ F (S1 ∩ S2) + F (S1 ∪ S2).
AP-based methods that leverage incidence relations achieve better convergence rates than classical AP algorithms both in the sequential and parallel optimization scenario.
The projection operation ΠBr (·) requires one to solve a min-norm problem by either exploiting the special forms of Fr or by using the general purpose algorithm of Wolfe [21].
We formally introduce one of the key concepts used in this work: incidence relations between elements of the ground set and the component submodular functions.
Our first result introduces a modification of the AP algorithm (3) that exploits incidence relations so as to decrease the required number of iterations from O(N 2R) to O(N μ 1).

To analyze solvers for the continuous optimization problem (2) that exploit the incidence structure of the functions, we make use of the skewed norm · 2,w with respect to some positve vector w that accounts for the fact that incidences are, in general, nonuniformly distributed.
By using the above lemma and the bound on κ∗, one can establish the following convergence rate for the IAP method.
After O(N μ 1 log(1/ )) iterations, the IAP algorithm for solving problem (5) outputs a pair of points (a, y) that satisfies dI(μ)(y, Ξ) ≤ .
The convergence rate of CD algorithms is linear if the objective function is component-wise smooth and -strong convex.

For all r ∈ C, if we perform projections onto Br with respect to the norm · 2,μC simultaneously in each iteration of the CDM, convergence is guaranteed as the value of the objective function remains bounded.
I.e., by setting μ 1 = N R, one always has θP 1,∞ ≥ αN R, which shows that parallelization cannot improve the convergence rate of the RCDM.
RCDM-G offers a much better convergence rate than RCDM-U since the sampling probability P produced by the greedy algorithm leads to a smaller value of θP 1,∞ compared to

Note that in the above examples of MAP inference, another way to decompose the submodular functions is available: as there are three natural layers of non-overlapping incidence sets, we can merge all vertical edges, all horizontal edges, and all superpixel regions into three components respectively.

Among the CD-based methods, ACDM-U offers the best performance in general, and RCDM-G slightly outperforms RCDM-U, since the greedy algorithm used for sampling produces a smaller θP 1,∞ than uniform sampling.
headline: We introduce a new approach to decomposable submodular function minimization  that exploits incidence relations
